Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES)-National Science Foundation (NSF) Special Session, Tampa FL, October 7-11, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Hart, Richard T.
Proposal Number: 1540059

This proposal seeks funding to support travel and offset registration fees for students, postdoctoral fellows, early career faculty and professionals, and speakers, inclusive of underrepresented groups and accessible to persons with disabilities, to participate in a BMES-NSF Special Session planned for the 2015 Biomedical Engineering Society Annual Meeting. The 2015 BMES Annual Meeting will be held in Tampa, Florida, October 7-11, 2015, and it will feature 19 parallel technical Program Tracks focused on the overall theme of "Innovation at the Interface." The BMES Annual Meeting serves as a primary vehicle for scientific sharing and dissemination of the latest advances in biomedical engineering, as well as a facilitator of important cross-fertilizations between the life sciences and engineering technologies, which foster a multi-disciplinary approach in the practice of Biomedical Engineering.

The BMES-NSF Special Session in particular builds on the success of a similar session held for the first time during the 2013 BMES Annual Meeting in Seattle, WA and for a second time during the 2014 BMES Annual Meeting in San Antonio, TX. Both of these previous sessions increased awareness of NSF-funded research in the area of Biomedical Engineering and allowed investigators to gain a better understanding of NSF funding opportunities and of how to prepare successful grant applications. The session also allowed for effective and in-depth interactions among attendees, NSF awardees and NSF program officers who attended the session. The objectives of the session planned for the 2015 Annual BMES Meeting are to 1) showcase NSF funded research and researchers; 2) foster collaboration and idea sharing through a networking reception; and 3) familiarize participants with NSF and NSF funding mechanisms and provide insight into strategies for preparing competitive grant proposals. The session will take place on Friday, October 9, 2015. It is expected that this session will recur on an annual basis to contribute to a comprehensive approach by BMES in partnership with NSF in ensuring development of a diverse, well educated, and technically competent biomedical engineering workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting is the premiere conference for the biomedical engineering field. It serves as a primary vehicle for scientific sharing and dissemination among the biomedical engineering community, and as a facilitator of important cross-fertilizations between the life sciences and engineering technologies to foster a multi-disciplinary approach in the practice of biomedical engineering. The 2015 BMES Annual Meeting was held in Tampa, Florida, from October 7-10, 2015. The meeting featured 19 Program Tracks with the theme of Innovation at the Interface.

Through this conference session grant, BMES used the funds from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to support travel for students, postdoctoral fellows, early career faculty and professionals, inclusive of underrepresented groups and accessible to persons with disabilities, to participate in the BMES-NSF Special Session on Research in Biomedical Engineering and Grant Writing at the 2015 BMES Annual Meeting in Tampa. The session took place on Friday, October 9, 2015 from 1:45pm to 5:00pm. The BMES-NSF Special Session focused on promoting and sustaining innovative research in biomedical engineering and essential elements to developing a successful NSF biomedical engineering grant proposal. Funds were also used to defray the costs of bringing in NSF awardees and reviewers to serve as presenters, mentors, and collaborators for novice and emerging investigators participating in the session.

The session included three research presentations from NSF CAREER grantees in various stages of their CAREER awards and one presentation from an NSF unsolicited grantee, a networking reception, a tutorial on essential elements on developing a successful proposal, and an interactive grant writing and submission panel discussion with five panelists, to include NSF program directors, awardees and reviewers.

The BMES Annual Meeting was an ideal venue for the intellectual content of the BMES-NSF Special Session because it stimulated conversations and research collaborations among biomedical engineering faculty and aspiring faculty. The BMES-NSF sponsored session brought together biomedical and bioengineering researchers and investigators, program directors and reviewers, who may not otherwise have had the opportunity to collaborate, exchange ideas or network around conducting and funding cutting-edge research in biomedical engineering. The session highlighted NSF funded research, informed participants on how to develop winning grant proposals and provided ample opportunity for networking and community building for those directing or aspiring to direct independent research.
